pages.text: Create offers many ways to transmit rotational force, which will be covered in this section. More entries may appear as your mastery of mechanisms and materials matures...$(br2)Remember to hover over their item for detailed information either here or in your inventory!

The most basic and cheapest way of transferring rotational force. This block transfers rotation along a straight axis.$(br2)There's encased variants as well, solid for mechanical or aesthetic use. Right-click with a Casing.

While these can be used as fancy-looking Shafts, their main use is to relay rotational force away from a Shaft. They will turn any other Cogwheels they're meshing with (interlocking teeth), which will reverse the direction of rotation.$(br2)The larger variant will only connect to the small ones diagonally (changing the rotation speed), and to other large cogwheels at 90 degrees.

Belts are placed using a Connector item. To create a Belt, right-click the Connector on a Shaft. You should see purple particles. These will turn green when you're looking at a valid second Shaft. Right-click again to finish the belt.

$(l)Stressful Transit$()$(br2)The default mod configuration settings give Belts a small stress cost, so be wary of using them as a power panacea. However, this cost pays for some handy benefits: Belts can move items and entities that land on top of them. Factory floors and escalators made simple!

The Gearbox is a simple block that relays rotation between four of its faces while reversing direction. Think of it as a set of cogwheels squished into a box!$(br2)You can make a vertical variant either by putting a gearbox in your crafting grid (and vice versa), or by rotating one with a Wrench.

A versatile method of transmission that works by connecting to other Chain Drives in a straight line. Their textures will change to indicate a network's been joined. They'll still link if there's a $(o)twist$(), but won't permit   a shaft straight out the end.

A variant of the Chain Drive that accepts redstone control. It has an internal $(o)gear ratio$() between the Shaft and Drive-network connections. Applying analog redstone to it will vary the ratio between 1:1 at 0 and 1:2 at 15 (Shaft:Drive).
An encased shaft that can be controlled by redstone. When powered by redstone, it will disconnect its internal Shaft and stop transmitting rotation through.
Similar to a Clutch, this is controlled by redstone. Normally behaves as a shaft. When powered by redstone, it will internally reverse rotation, behaving like a Gearbox.
A more advanced Gearshift that can be programmed with various simple behaviors in a GUI. Sending it a redstone signal will cause it to begin stepping through the assigned behaviors.

A high-tech device for regulating speed. Has a front panel where a number can be scrolled to set - when given a rotational input, it will try to drive a Large Cogwheel mounted above it at the set speed.
